title: Amir Ghalenoei
text:
Ardeshir "Amir" Ghalenoei (, born 21 November 1963 in <a href="Tehran">Tehran</a>, Iran) is an Iranian <a href="association%20football">football</a> coach and former player who currently manages <a href="Gol%20Gohar%20Sirjan%20F.C.">Gol Gohar Sirjan</a>. He has been the most successful coach in the <a href="Iran%20Pro%20League">Iran Pro League</a> and managed several clubs, including <a href="Esteghlal%20Tehran%20FC">Esteghlal</a>, <a href="Mes%20Kerman%20F.C.">Mes Kerman</a>, <a href="Sepahan%20S.C.">Sepahan S.C.</a> and <a href="Tractor%20S.C.">Tractor</a>, with two of which he won a total of five championships and two <a href="Hazfi%20Cup">Hazfi Cup</a> titles. He was also the head coach of <a href="Iran%20national%20football%20team">Iran national football team</a> from August 2006 to July 2007 where he managed the team for the <a href="2007%20AFC%20Asian%20Cup">2007 AFC Asian Cup</a> where Iran was eliminated in the quarter-finals.
Club career.
Rah Ahan.
Ardeshir (Amir) Ghalenoei was born on 21 November 1963 in Tehran, Iran. His father, a taxi driver, died when Amir was only thirteen years old. He began his career in the late 1970s after passing a technical test for <a href="Rah%20Ahan%20F.C.">Rah Ahan</a>, one of the oldest clubs in the Iranian football. He played for the club's youth team for two years and was promoted to the first team squad in 1981 by <a href="Nasser%20Ebrahimi">Nasser Ebrahimi</a>. He had a good performance there and scored three goals during the domestic Tehran Hazfi cup. Ghalenoei left the club after the club's head coach signed for <a href="Shahin%20F.C.">Shahin</a>.
Shahin.
When Ebrahimi became <a href="Shahin%20F.C.">Shahin</a>'s coach, Ghalenoei moved to Shahin along with him. Shahin had several national players such as <a href="Nasrollah%20Abdollahi">Nasrollah Abdollahi</a>, <a href="Mehdi%20Dinvarzadeh">Mehdi Dinvarzadeh</a>, <a href="Hamid%20Majd%20Teymouri">Hamid Majd Teymouri</a>. Ebrahimi left the club in 1984, succeeded by <a href="Mehrab%20Shahrokhi">Mehrab Shahrokhi</a> who was the head coach for a short period before being replaced by Nasrollah Abdollahi. Ghalenoei became the club's captain after the retirement of Dinvarzadeh. During his time in Shahin, he helped the team to finish as runner-up in two <a href="Tehran%20Football%20Competitions">Tehran leagues</a> in 1985 and 1986.
He played his last match for Shahin in a 2–0 victory against <a href="Persepolis%20F.C.">Persepolis</a> where both goals were on Ghalenoei's assists. He left the team in the middle of the 1987–88 season and signed with the Qatari club of <a href="Al-Sadd">Al-Sadd</a>.
Al-Sadd.
He signed a one-and-a-half years contract with <a href="Al-Sadd">Al-Sadd</a> in 1987. He helped his side to two domestic league title and one <a href="Emir%20of%20Qatar">Emir of Qatar</a> (FA Cup) title. Al-Sadd also won <a href="1988%E2%80%9389%20Asian%20Club%20Championship">1988–89 edition</a> of <a href="AFC%20Champions%20League">AFC Champions League</a> in spring of 1989 after defeating <a href="Al-Rasheed">Al-Rasheed</a> in the final. However Ghalenoei had already left the club and returned to Iran, and thus was not a member of the Asian champions squad.
Esteghlal.
He joined <a href="Esteghlal%20F.C.">Esteghlal</a> in July 1989 and played for the club until his retirement. He made his debut in a game against <a href="Persepolis%20F.C.">Persepolis</a> in a quarter final <a href="Hazfi%20Cup">Hazfi Cup</a> match where he lost his penalty kick.
He won the Iran league title in his first full season (1989–90) at the club in spring 1990. Esteghlal also won the <a href="Asian%20Club%20Championship">Asian Club Championship</a> on the following season (1990–91) after nearly twenty years.
Ghalenoei lost most of the next season (1991–92) due to a heavy injury. At that season, Esteghlal could not obtain an entry to the next season (1992–93) of Azadegan league and thus was asked to play in the <a href="Iran%20Football%27s%203rd%20Division">3rd Division</a> for one season. This meant the departure of many players like <a href="Ahmad%20Reza%20Abedzadeh">Ahmad Reza Abedzadeh</a>, <a href="Shahrokh%20Bayani">Shahrokh Bayani</a>, <a href="Majid%20Namjoo-Motlagh">Majid Namjoo-Motlagh</a>, <a href="Samad%20Marfavi">Samad Marfavi</a> and <a href="Reza%20Ahadi">Reza Ahadi</a> but Ghalenoei remained at the team and was chosen as the club's new captain. Esteghlal again rose to the top level of Iranian football in 1994–95 and was ranked second on their first season back to the competition. Ghalenoei also scored twice in the final game of the following season (1995–96) <a href="Hazfi%20Cup">Hazfi Cup</a>. In his last season in Esteghlal, they started off successfully both in the Iranian and Asian Cup Winners' Cup, but could not sustain the good performance. Their head coach, <a href="Mansour%20Pourheidari">Mansour Pourheidari</a> – who had the club to the Asian glory – resigned mid season and <a href="Nasser%20Hejazi">Nasser Hejazi</a> was appointed as the head coach and finished the league with sixth position. He retired at the end of this season after missing many matches due to injury.
He was the captain of Esteghlal in the last four years of his career, known as "General", a title bestowed on him by fans due to his outstanding skills in leading the team during his career as the club.
International career.
He was first invited to Iran national B football team in 1985 by <a href="Nasser%20Ebrahimi">Nasser Ebrahimi</a>, a coach that he began his career with, and showed a good performance. He was invited on following year to the national team by <a href="Parviz%20Dehdari">Parviz Dehdari</a> and made his debut against <a href="China%20PR%20national%20football%20team">China PR</a>. However, he missed several international tournaments despite his good performance. For example, when he played in Al-Sadd, he was not invited to the national team squad for <a href="1988%20AFC%20Asian%20Cup">1988 AFC Asian Cup</a> because he was a member of a foreign club. For the <a href="1990%20Asian%20Games">1990 Asian Games</a> held in Beijing, he was not invited because there several talented players in position he played. He was also injured before the <a href="1992%20AFC%20Asian%20Cup">1992 AFC Asian Cup</a> and missed it.
He was invited to <a href="Iran%20national%20football%20team">Iran national football team</a> again in 1993 by <a href="Ali%20Parvin">Ali Parvin</a> and played against <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina%20national%20football%20team">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> on 12 September 1993. He also played in final round of <a href="1994%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1994 FIFA World Cup</a> Qualification (in Qatar) and performed well especially against <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan</a> and <a href="North%20Korea%20national%20football%20team">North Korea</a>. His last national match was against <a href="Oman%20national%20football%20team">Oman</a> in <a href="Tehran">Tehran</a>. He captained Iran for one cap and scored one goal against Kuwait.
Ghalenoei was injured several times during his playing career, first in 1992 and the second in 1996 that was very strenuous and forced him to retire form football. This injury is still with him and he had several surgeries in his post-playing career.
Managerial career.
Keshavarz and Bargh Tehran.
Ghalenoei is the first Iranian football manager who passed <a href="Manchester%20United">Manchester United</a> managerial class after taking Europe grade C at <a href="Bayer%20Leverkusen">Bayer Leverkusen</a> football club six-month earlier.
His first managerial experience was with <a href="Keshavarz%20F.C.">Keshavarz</a> in 1999 but was unsuccessful. He was later in charge of an <a href="Azadegan%20League">Azadegan League</a> side, <a href="Bargh%20Tehran%20F.C.">Bargh Tehran</a> from 2001 to 2002 where he could not lead his team to the promotion play-off, despite collecting 31 points in 20 matches. He faced <a href="Persepolis%20F.C.">Persepolis</a> in the <a href="Hazfi%20Cup">Hazfi Cup</a> where Persepolis defeated his team 1–2 in extra time.
Esteghlal Ahvaz.
After serving as the Esteghlal's interim head coach in 5 matches in spring 2002 and winning the Hazfi cup with this team, he was appointed as Esteghlal's assistant coach for the next season (2002–03). However, he left the team before the season started and joined <a href="Esteghlal%20Ahvaz">Esteghlal Ahvaz</a> in the 5th week of the 2002–03 league.
He was appointed as head coach of Esteghlal Ahvaz in the <a href="Iran%20Pro%20League">Iran Pro League</a> in November 2002 to keep the club in the league. Esteghlal Ahvaz was in a winless row and was the last team in the league table when Ghalenoei joined the team. He earned 24 points in 21 matches. After a draw with <a href="Malavan%20F.C.">Malavan</a> at the last week of the season, Esteghlal Ahvaz remained at the league and ended the season at the 11th place.
Esteghlal.
2003–04.
He was officially named as Esteghlal's head coach before the <a href="2003%E2%80%9304%20Iran%20Pro%20League">2003–04 season</a> by the club chairman <a href="Mohammad%20Gharib">Mohammad Gharib</a>. He succeeded <a href="Mansour%20Pourheidari">Mansour Pourheidari</a> who Ghalenoei was his assistant for the years. At the end of the season, Esteghlal lost the league after a defeat to <a href="Esteghlal%20Ahvaz%20F.C.">Esteghlal Ahvaz</a>, team Ghalenoei coached in 2002 in the final match.
2004–05.
Ghalenoei began his second year as the head coach of Esteghlal, which his side was again in the championship race but ended the season at the third place with a goal difference with <a href="Zob%20Ahan%20F.C.">Zob Ahan</a> in the second rank. One of the best days of Ghalenoei in this season was seen in <a href="Tehran%20derby">Tehran derby</a>, when Esteghlal defeated its rival 3–2 with a late goal from <a href="Pirouz%20Ghorbani">Pirouz Ghorbani</a>. Esteghlal forward <a href="Reza%20Enayati">Reza Enayati</a> was the top scorer of the league and Esteghlal had the best attacking style between the teams of the league.
2005–06.
At the next and final season at Esteghlal in the first spell, Ghalenoei earn the <a href="Iran%20Pro%20League">Iran Pro League</a> title for the first time with fifty-nine points ahead of <a href="Pas%20Tehran%20F.C.">Pas Tehran</a>. <a href="Reza%20Enayati">Reza Enayati</a> also became the league top scorer for the second constitutive time and Esteghlal had the best defense style. Ghalenoei left the Esteghlal at the end of the season to succeed <a href="Branko%20Ivankovi%C4%87">Branko Ivanković</a> as the head coach of <a href="Iran%20national%20football%20team">Iranian national football team</a>.
2008–09.
Ghalenoei returned to Esteghlal in May 2008 after two seasons. Esteghlal saw a bad season in the last year after ending 13th with the management of <a href="Nasser%20Hejazi">Nasser Hejazi</a> and <a href="Firouz%20Karimi">Firouz Karimi</a>. Ghalenoei led the team in the remaining matches of <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Hazfi%20Cup">Hazfi Cup</a> which Esteghlal won the trophy after defeating <a href="Pegah%20Gilan%20F.C.">Pegah Gilan</a> in the final. Esteghlal won the league at the final day after defeating <a href="Payam%20Mashhad%20F.C.">Payam Mashhad</a> and <a href="Zob%20Ahan%20F.C.">Zob Ahan</a> lose to <a href="Foolad%20F.C.">Foolad</a>. <a href="Arash%20Borhani">Arash Borhani</a> was also the team and league's top scorer. Esteghlal have a bad starting in <a href="2008%20AFC%20Champions%20League">AFC Champions League</a>, eliminating in the group stage. At the end of the tournament, Ghalenoei resigned from his post after did not agree with a new contract with club chairman.
2012–13.
After spending one season at Tractor, he signed a two years contract with Esteghlal on 29 May 2012. He named former <a href="Saipa%20F.C.">Saipa</a> head coach <a href="Majid%20Saleh">Majid Saleh</a> as his assistant. Esteghlal also bought many stars like <a href="Amir%20Hossein%20Sadeghi">Amir Hossein Sadeghi</a>, <a href="Rodrigo%20Tosi">Rodrigo Tosi</a> and <a href="Siavash%20Akbarpour">Siavash Akbarpour</a> from <a href="Tractor%20S.C.">Tractor</a>, <a href="Amin%20Manouchehri">Amin Manouchehri</a> from <a href="Saipa%20F.C.">Saipa</a>, <a href="Fabio%20Januario">Fabio Januario</a> from <a href="Sepahan%20F.C.">Sepahan</a>, <a href="Javad%20Nekounam">Javad Nekounam</a> from <a href="CA%20Osasuna">Osasuna</a> and <a href="Liam%20Reddy">Liam Reddy</a> from <a href="Sydney%20FC">Sydney FC</a>. They also kept their players except <a href="Andranik%20Teymourian">Andranik Teymourian</a> who was sold to <a href="Al%20Kharaitiyat%20SC">Al-Kharitiyath</a> and <a href="Goran%20Jerkovi%C4%87%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201986%29">Goran Jerković</a> to <a href="Buriram%20United%20F.C.">Buriram United</a>. His side started the league disappointing in the early weeks but soon obtain leaders after a 1–0 away win over <a href="Sepahan%20F.C.">Sepahan</a> but lose the winter championship to Sepahan at the final match of the first half. They also bought <a href="Hassan%20Ashjari">Hassan Ashjari</a>, <a href="Farzad%20Hatami">Farzad Hatami</a>, <a href="Vicente%20Arze">Vicente Arze</a> and <a href="Iman%20Mousavi">Iman Mousavi</a> in the January transfers window and <a href="Farhad%20Majidi">Farhad Majidi</a> returned to the first team after one season. They also released <a href="Ferydoon%20Zandi">Ferydoon Zandi</a>, <a href="Amin%20Manouchehri">Amin Manouchehri</a>, <a href="Milad%20Meydavoudi">Milad Meydavoudi</a>, <a href="Rodrigo%20Tosi">Rodrigo Tosi</a> and <a href="Liam%20Reddy">Liam Reddy</a>. They began the second half successfully and not lost until last match against <a href="S.C.%20Damash">Damash</a>. Esteghlal also began <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20Hazfi%20Cup">season's Hazfi Cup</a> with a 4–0 win at <a href="Saipa%20F.C.">Saipa</a>. On 5 May 2013, his side celebrated their 8th <a href="Iran%20Pro%20League">Iran Pro League</a> title, 3rd under Ghalenoei with a 1–0 win over <a href="Foolad%20F.C.">Foolad</a> with goal from <a href="Javad%20Nekounam">Javad Nekounam</a>. His side also reaches to the Quarter-finals of the <a href="2013%20AFC%20Champions%20League">Champions League</a> after ending group match in the first rank over <a href="Al-Hilal%20F.C.">Al-Hilal</a> and also <a href="Al%20Shabab%20Al%20Arabi%20Club%20Dubai">Al-Shabab</a> in the Round of 16.
2013–14.
Ghalenoei stayed at Esteghlal despite bids from <a href="Al%20Ain%20FC">Al-Ain</a> and <a href="Mes%20Kerman%20F.C.">Mes Kerman</a> for their vacant managerial position. Esteghlal bought few players like <a href="Ahmad%20Jamshidian">Ahmad Jamshidian</a>, <a href="Mohammad%20Mehdi%20Nazari">Mohammad Mehdi Nazari</a>, <a href="Pejman%20Nouri">Pejman Nouri</a>, <a href="Mohammad%20Ghazi">Mohammad Ghazi</a> and <a href="Alireza%20Vahedi%20Nikbakht">Alireza Vahedi Nikbakht</a>. <a href="Fardin%20Abedini">Fardin Abedini</a> also returned from the loan. His team also kept many of the last season's players but <a href="Mojtaba%20Jabbari">Mojtaba Jabbari</a> doesn't extended his contract and joined <a href="Sepahan%20F.C.">Sepahan</a>. <a href="Iman%20Mousavi">Iman Mousavi</a>, <a href="Abbas%20Mohammadrezaei">Abbas Mohammadrezaei</a>, <a href="Farzad%20Hatami">Farzad Hatami</a>, <a href="Hassan%20Ashjari">Hassan Ashjari</a>, <a href="Maysam%20Baou">Maysam Baou</a>, <a href="Ali%20Hamoudi">Ali Hamoudi</a> also sold and <a href="Vicente%20Arze">Vicente Arze</a> left the team and returned to <a href="R.%20Charleroi%20S.C.">Charleroi</a> after the end of his loan contract. Esteghlal also won <a href="Damash%20Karaj%20F.C.">Damash Karaj</a> and <a href="FC%20Dynamo%20Kiev">Dynamo Kiev</a> during pre-season friendly matches. Esteghlal began the league with a 2–1 away win over <a href="Gostaresh%20Foolad%20F.C.">Gostaresh Foolad</a>. Esteghlal finished the season in a disappointing 5th place, knocked out in the Group stage of <a href="2014%20AFC%20Champions%20League">AFC Champions League</a>. Esteghlal also knocked out by <a href="Mes%20Kerman%20F.C.">Mes Kerman</a> in the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Hazfi%20Cup">semi-finals</a>.
2014–15.
Ghalenoei promised to begin a new project in Esteghlal with signing youth players from Esteghlal's academy and other teams, which he do so in 2003. At the end of the season, he was sacked from the team due to his weak results and finishing the season in the 6th place.
Iranian national team.
<a href="IRIFF">IRIFF</a> appointed Ghalenoei as head coach of the Iran national football team on 17 July 2006 to succeed <a href="Branko%20Ivankovi%C4%87">Branko Ivanković</a>. After finishing first in the qualifying round 2 points ahead of South Korea and then finishing first in the group stage of the final tournament in Malaysia, Iran lost to <a href="South%20Korea%20national%20football%20team">South Korea</a> in the penalty shoot-outs of the Quarters Final match and was eliminated from the <a href="2007%20Asian%20Cup">2007 Asian Cup</a>. Ghalenoei was heavily criticized by the press. After a period of discussion in the Iranian football federation, his contract was not renewed and national team was left with a caretaker manager for several months.
Mes Kerman.
Despite being in negotiations with <a href="Uzbek%20League">Uzbek League</a> champions <a href="FC%20Pakhtakor%20Tashkent">FC Pakhtakor Tashkent</a> on 1 January 2008, Ghalenoei signed a contract until the end of the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Persian%20Gulf%20Cup">2007–08</a> season with <a href="Iran%20Pro%20League">Iran Pro League</a> side <a href="Mes%20Kerman%20F.C.">Mes Kerman</a>. where he led the club to finish among the top teams of the second half-season, even though it was at the bottom of the table when he accepted the job.
Sepahan.
2009–10.
He signed for <a href="Sepahan%20F.C.">Sepahan</a> in summer 2009. Where he won the <a href="Persian%20Gulf%20Cup">Persian Gulf Cup</a> for the second time in a row, but failed to qualify for last 16 in the <a href="AFC%20Champions%20League">AFC Champions League</a> for the second time in the row.
2010–11.
Ghalenoei renewed his contract with Sepahan for the upcoming season, where he won the league for the third time in the row and second time with Sepahan. Sepahan had excellent performance in <a href="AFC%20Champions%20League">AFC Champions League</a> as well and qualified for quarter final with five wins in seven matches. However, after that he left Sepahan on 4 June 2011 due to conflict with the new board director though he had led the club to the quarter finals of the <a href="AFC%20Champions%20League">AFC Champions League</a> as the best team of the west Asian division.
Tractor.
2011–12.
On 13 June 2011, he was named as new <a href="Tractor%20S.C.">Tractor</a> head coach. He led the team to the runners-up of the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Iran%20Pro%20League">2011–12 season</a>, one point behind of winner, his former-side <a href="Sepahan%20F.C.">Sepahan</a> and qualified to the <a href="2013%20AFC%20Champions%20League">AFC Champions League</a> for the first time in the club history.
2015–16.
On 9 December 2015, Ghalenoei returned to Tractor with signing a one-and-a half-year contract.
Club statistics.
These statistics include all formal club-level games since Ghalenoei started coaching at the highest division of Iran football in 2002: Iran Pro League, Hazfi Cup, and AFC Champions League.
